div.p:
Allow me to point out, dear Mr Fitzgibbon, that the ploughed stripe of ground along the Yarra would required
sic, no 'be' before this.
to be harrowed, for which process it would be now well fit. I am anxious to put into it young trees very soon, & the tree-seeds whenever night frosts are not likely to be any longer severe. The process of raking the ground would be a very tedious one. So perhaps the City Council would be so kind to have the harrowing done. The young trees are already in readiness. I must also ask the Gentlemen of the Council to allow the two men, now at work, when they have finished the willow planting, to assist in the planting of the ploughed ground for a few weeks. We will then make a good work of it. I have also to tender my best thanks for the graceful manner, in which to my humble services was alluded in the Argus,
follow up in Argus.
when the very extensive and laudable operations of the City Council were detailed. At the close of the planting I shall not fail to submit a report.

div.p:
Ferd. von Mueller
M's letter was read at a meeting of the Melbourne City Council Health Committee, 5 August 1868: 'Chairman instructed to report to Council recommending that authority be given for the continued employment of the two men for one fortnight Mr Felstead instructed to cause the furrow along the River Bank to be [moved].' (Unit 1, VPRS 4039, PROV).
